docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
The book of notes I wish I had when starting out with Java. Three resources:

  • Use the official API docs
  • Use a Java 8 Book
  • Java 8 distribution of choice

docs.title: Deploying locally
docs.text:
• mkdocs new [dir-name] - Create a new project.
  • mkdocs serve - Start the live-reloading docs server.
  • mkdocs build - Build the documentation site.
  • mkdocs -h - Print help message and exit.

docs.title: Project layout
docs.text:
mkdocs.yml    # The configuration file.
docs/
    index.md  # The documentation homepage.
    ...       # Other markdown pages, images and other files.

docs.title: You can even do mathematics
docs.text: \[ \operatorname{ker} f=\{g\in G:f(g)=e_{H}\}{\mbox{.}} \]

docs.title: ArrayLists
docs.text:
Declaring an ArrayList. Use non-primitive type in the declaration, i.e. wrapper classes, this is typical of Template Classes, valid for the other Collections as well. If you need to remove items from the middle of the start of a list, or anywhere rather than the absolute end, you'd need to use a LinkedList.

List<Integer> arrayList = new ArrayList<Integer>();

docs.title: Import statements
docs.text:
To Import the following collections:

import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.List;

docs.title: Basic Operations (adding ..)
docs.text:
// Adding
arrayList.add(3);
arrayList.add(45);
arrayList.add(929);

// Retrieving: Specify the Index
arrayList.get(0); // Index 0

// Removing: Specify the Index // Be Careful
arrayList.remove(numbers.size() - 1);

docs.title: Cycling through the elements of an ArrayList
docs.text:
We can iterate over a set using a certain kind of loops:

// Indexed for-loop iteration
for(int i = 0; i < arrayList.size(); i++){
  // Printing all the elements as console output
  System.out.println(arrayList.get(i));
}

// Iteration 
for(Integer value: arrayList){
  // 
  int value = (int) arrayList.get(value);
  System.out.println(value);
}

Note that:

map.keySet();

returns a Collection called "Set", which is itself a data structure.

docs.title: Passing an ArrayList Object to a method (List<> Interface)
docs.text:
This is how you pass a map to a method. Notice how it is possible to pass the interface's type List<> to the method

public static void Main(String[] args){

  List<Integer> arrayList = new ArrayList<Integer>();
  testArrayList(arrayList);
}

public static void testArrayList(ArrayList<Integer> arrayList){

 // Operations
 // arrayList.get(key);
}

docs.title: Natural Order
docs.text:
For strings natural order is alphabetical order, for numbers is the ordinal sorting. You can define a natural order of your classes.

Collections.sort(myList);

docs.title: Which Java Collection to choose for which purpose
Lists
docs.text:
• Store Lists of Objects
  • Duplicates are allowed
  • Objects remain in order
  • Elements are indexed via an integer
  • Checking for a particular item in list is slow
  • Looking an item up by index is fast
  • Iterating through lists is relatively fast
  • Note: you can sort lists if you want to
// If you only add or remove items at end of the list, use ArrayList
List<String> list1 = new ArrayList<String>();

// Removing or adding items elsewhere in the list
List<String> list2 = new LinkedList<String>();

docs.title: Sets
docs.text:
• Only store unique values
  • Great for removing duplicates
  • Not Indexed, unlike lists, so there's no particular position, no positioning
  • Very fast to check if a particular object exists
  • If you want to use your own objects, you must implement hashCode() and equals()
  • You decide whether objects are the same of not by implementing hashCode() and equals()
// Order is not important and it might change: HashSet
Set<String> set1 = new HashSet<String>();

// Sorted in Natural Order (alphabetical, numerical ascending order), must implement Comparable for custom types
Set<String> set2 = new TreeSet<String>();

// Elements remain in the order they were added
Set<String> set3 = new LinkedHashSet<String>();

docs.title: Maps
docs.text:
• Key-value pairs (i.e. <String, Integer>, <String, Integer, Double, String>, ...)
  • Retrieving a value by key is fast
  • Iterating over maps is slow
  • Maps are not optimised for iteration (if doing so, iterate through the keys)
  • If you want to use your own objects as keys, you must implement hashCode() and equals()
// Keys not in any particular order, and order liable to change
Map<String, String> map1 = new HashMap<String, String>();

// Keys sorted in natural Order (alphabetical, numerical ascending order)
Map<String, String> map2 = new TreeMap<String, String>();

// Keys remain in order added
Map<String, String> map3 = new LinkedHashMap<String, String>();

docs.title: The Collection Root Interface
docs.text:
// A root interface more flexible (for example can change from Map to Set), 
// so if we wanna in a common use, just Collection ia enough.

Collection<Customer> customers = new ArrayList<>();

// Since it's a root interface, we can use the same way as List, Map to access, remove etc.
customers.add(s);

//  method 'clear()' is defined in java.util.Collection interface
//  Remove all the elements in List/Set/Queue/Map(remove both Key and Value)

//  Example in lab3 WorkingHours.java

    workingHours.clear();
//  Remove first, make sure add brand new time period after.

docs.title: The return value of Collection method
docs.text:
public Collection<String> restaurants() {
        return new LinkedList<>(restaurants.keySet());
}
    // keySet() is a method of Map Interface，return all the Key's view of Set<String>

    // These codes means: 
    // Transfer all the Key of 'restaurants' into a Set, and then use this Set create a new LinkedList.

docs.title: Hash Map
docs.text:
Maps store pair values where one member is called the "key" and the other one is called the "value". The HashMap does not maintain order, hence, for this purpose there's the need for SortedMaps.

HashMap<Integer, String> hashMap = new HashMap<Integer, String>();

LinkedHashMap<Integer, String> linkedhashMap = new LinkedHashMap<Integer, String>();

TreeMap<Integer, String> treeMap = new TreeMap<Integer, String>();

docs.title: Import statements
docs.text:
To Import the following collections:

import java.util.HashMap;
import java.util.Map;
import java.util.LinkedHashMap;
import java.util.TreeMap;

docs.title: Populating, retrieving and other operations
docs.text:
The put method is what populates the map

map.put(5, "Five"); // 5 is a primitive type, but Java autoboxes with the respective wrapper class

The get method is used to retrieve values off the Map

map.get(0); // I pass the index to the get method

docs.title: Passing a Map Object to a method
docs.text:
This is how you pass a map to a method. Notice how it is possible to pass the interface's type Map<> to the method

public static void Main(String[] args){

  TreeMap<Integer, String> treeMap = new TreeMap<Integer, String>();
  testMap(treeMap);
}

public static void testMap(Map<Integer, String> map){

 // Operations
 // map.get(key);
}

docs.title: Iterating through the Map
docs.text:
We can iterate over a set using a foreach loop.

Map.Entry<Integer, String>

for(Map.Entry<Integer, String> entry: map.entrySet()){
  // Returns the value corresponding to that key
  String value = map.get(key);
}

for(Integer key: map.keySet()){
  // Returns the value corresponding to that key
  String value = map.get(key);
}

Note that:

map.keySet();

returns a Collection called "Set", which is itself a data structure.

docs.title: Natural Order
docs.text: For strings natural order is alphabetical order, for numbers is the ordinal sorting. You can define a natural order of your classes.

docs.title: LinkedList and the List Interface
docs.text:
Declaring a LinkedList. Use non-primitive type in the declaration, i.e. wrapper classes, this is typical of Template Classes, valid for the other Collections as well. If you need to remove items from the middle of the start of a list, or anywhere rather than the absolute end, you'd need to use a LinkedList.

List<Integer> linkedList = new LinkedList<Integer>();

docs.title: Import statements
docs.text:
To Import the following collections:

import java.util.LinkedList;
import java.util.List;

docs.title: Sorted Maps and the Map Interface - Java Collections Framework
docs.text:
There are different implementation of the Map Interface. The first element is identified as the "key" of the data structure.

HashMap<Integer, String> hashMap = new HashMap<Integer, String>();

LinkedHashMap<Integer, String> LhashMap = new LinkedHashMap<Integer, String>();

TreeMap<Integer, String> treeMap = new TreeMap<Integer, String>();

docs.title: Import statements
docs.text:
To Import the following collections:

import java.util.HashMap;
import java.util.Map;
import java.util.LinkedHashMap;
import java.util.TreeMap;

docs.title: Passing a Map Object to a method
docs.text:
This is how you pass a map to a method. Notice how it is possible to pass the interface's type Map<> to the method

public static void Main(String[] args){

  TreeMap<Integer, String> treeMap = new TreeMap<Integer, String>();
  testMap(treeMap);
}

public static void testMap(Map<Integer, String> map){

 // Operations
 // map.get(key);
}

docs.title: Cycling through the elements of a SortedMap
docs.text:
We can iterate over a set using a certain kind of loops:

for(Integer key: map.keySet()){
  // Returns the value corresponding to that key
  String value = map.get(key);
}

Note that:

map.keySet();

returns a Collection called "Set", which is itself a data structure.

docs.title: Scan
docs.text:
Just read an Int with Scan

System.out.println("n partecipants: ");
Scanner scan = new Scanner(System.in);
int n = scan.nextInt();

Read an entire input and then collect the values with "split"

Scanner scanner = new Scanner(System.in);
String input = scanner.next();
int words[] = input.split(' ');

docs.title: Buffered Reader
docs.text:
BufferedReader in = new BufferedReader(new InputStreamReader(System.in)); 
String[] input = new String[2];     
input = in.readLine().split(" "); 
int a; 
int b; 
a = Integer.parseInt(input[0]); 
b = Integer.parseInt(input[1]); 
System.out.println("You input: " + a + " and " + b);

docs.title: Reading a File in Java
docs.text:
We have three classes for reading from a Java file:

  • Scanner
  • FileReader
  • BufferedReader

We also have a class called File that allows us to instantiate a File Object, which is the File representation in Java.

docs.title: Reaching the file in the File System
docs.text:
In Eclipse, the root of the project folder is where the file system search starts at.

If Somewhere in the file system, on Windows

String fileName = "C:\\users\\username\\Desktop\\folder\\file.csv"

If in the src/ directory, inside the project folder, in Eclipse

String fileName = "src\\file.csv"

If in the root of the project folder, in Eclipse

String fileName = "file.csv"

docs.title: Reading Files with the Scanner class
docs.text:
Let's create a File Object, which will be a Java representation of your file.

File textFile = new File(fileName);

Reading file using the Scanner class, I pass the file Object I want to read

Scanner in = new Scanner(textFile);

// Reading the first integer of the file, supposing the first thing to read
// is a number
in.nextInt();

// Reading the new line character after the first one
in.nextLine();

// Reading it line by line
while(in.hasNextLine()){
  String line = in.nextLine();
  // Operations with the line
}

// Closing the file
in.close();

docs.title: Reading files with the FileReader class
docs.text:
import java.io.*;

File file = new File("text.txt");

docs.title: Reading a CSV File with the BufferedReader class
docs.text:
Importing the necessary libraries

import java.io.*;

The location of the File in an Eclipse Project Folder

String file = "src\\students.csv";

Instantiating the BufferedReader class as "null", for now

BufferedReader reader = null;

Will be using the following to read each line of our file

String line = "";

Let's create a Try/Catch/Finally block to manage the eventual errors. Note: Eclipse will probably suggest its own way to managing error through try and catch blocks. Better using the following.

try{
  // Finishing instantiating our Reader
  // Withing the parentheses we pass an anonymous FileReader
  reader = new BufferedReader(new FileReader(file));
  // This while loop is going to continuosly read the next line
  // and checking if it is not "null"
  while((line = reader.readLine()) != null){

    // We specify our character, that's a String, where we want to split our line at.
    // Then, after taking all of the values of this very row in this CSV, we assing them
    // to an array of type String.
    String[] row = line.split(",");

    // Printing them on console ( yet to write )
    for(String index: row){
      System.out.println();
    }

  }
} 
// Let's catch all exceptions, since there's a moltitude of exceptions that
// could be catched, such as FileNotFoundException or IOException
catch(Exception e)
{
  // If something goes wrong, this prints the Stack Trace
  e.printStackTrace();
}
finally{

  // In programs were Scanner and BufferedReader are opened, it's good
  // practice to close them in the end. Also, it's good practice to surround them
  // with try and catch blocks.

  try{
    reader.close();
  }catch(IOException e){
    e.printStackTrace();
  }
}

docs.title: Maven
docs.text: Maven is a build automation and project management tool for Java (and other JVM) projects. It resolves dependencies, downloads them, compiles your code, runs tests, packages artifacts, and even deploys them to repositories. You simply list the libraries you need (e.g. JUnit) in your POM, then, it looks in your local cache (usually ~/.m2/repository); if it’s not there, it downloads them from remote repositories (by default Maven Central) and caches them for you

docs.title: The configuration file: pom.xml
docs.text:
Describes your project in a POM (Project Object Model). You can create a “parent” POM that aggregates several sub-modules, which means that supports multi-module projects.

A pom.xml file sits at the root of your project.

docs.title: Maven project structure
docs.text:
Using a standard directory layout (src/main/java, src/test/java, etc.) means you rarely have to configure where your code lives.

Maven expects:

src/
  └── main/
      └── java/
            └── Package1/
  └── test/
      └── java/
            └── TestSuite1/

If you want you can omit the src/test repository, and just go with src/main. But, on src/main, I'd suggest to put a Main.java within the package:

<configuration>
    <!-- Fully qualified name of your entry point -->
    <mainClass>Package1.Main</mainClass>
</configuration>

and, on top of the Main.java file:

package Package1;

having this in the pom.xml ensures the fact that you've got yourself an entrypoint, a Main, to your application.

docs.title: Maven goals
docs.text: After setting up the project structure, you can run Maven goals like mvn clean, mvn compile, mvn test, mvn package, mvn install.

docs.title: Interfaces in Java
docs.text:
// If a class implements an Interface, then all the abstract method in this Interface defined must be implemented. Otherwise compiler report bugs. 

/*
compareTo(T other): Returns:

Negative integer if the current object is "less than" other.
Zero if the current object is "equal to" other.
Positive integer if the current object is "greater than" other.
*/

Example: 
public class Restaurant implements Comparable<Restaurant> {

    @Override
    public int compareTo(Restaurant o) {
        return this.getName().compareTo(o.getName());
    }

}

docs.title: About method in java.lang
docs.text: Automatically available package.

docs.title: 1 split
docs.text:
/* The split method belongs to the String class, which is part of the java.lang package. This package is automatically imported in all Java programs
*/

// How to use: Splits a String into an array of substrings using ":" as the delimiter.

 String[] hm = time.split(":");
//  "10:30" → ["10", "30"] 
// Example from lab3 Time.java

docs.title: 2 parseInt
docs.text:
//   Converts a String to an int.

    h = Integer.parseInt(hm[0]);

// Transfer first element of String 'hm' to an integer.

docs.title: Object class
docs.text: By polymorphism, we can see any instance of any class as an Object instance. Object is the universal reference type.

docs.title: enum in Java
docs.text:
//   Using pre-defined enum value only, protect code from illegal input. In java, it can contains method or interface.

//Example 1: 
    public enum OrderStatus{
        ORDERD,
        READY,
        DELIEVED;
    }

    Order order = new Order();

    order.setStatus(OrderStatus.READY);
    //  enum value accepted only  ↑ 

// Example 2:
    public enum PaymentMethod {
    CASH("现金", 0),      // Cash, 0% of Service charge. 
    CARD("信用卡", 1.5),   // Credit card, 1.5%
    PAYPAL("贝宝", 2.0);   // Online, 2.0%

 // Counting Service charge:
    double amount = 1000.0;
    double fee = PaymentMethod.CARD.calculateFee(amount);

docs.title: Streams (Java8)
docs.text:
Motivation:

Streams are Monads, thus playing a big part in bringing functional programming to Java: In functional programming, a monad is a structure that represents computations defined as sequences of steps. A type with a monad structure defines what it means to chain operations, or nest functions of that type together.

quote: this man

docs.title: Lambda Expressions
docs.text:
To put it simple, see how the following code gets shortened at each step:

Step 1

List<String> names = Arrays.asList("peter", "anna", "mike", "xenia");
Collections.sort(names, new Comparator<String>() {
@Override
public int compare(String a, String b) {
return b.compareTo(a);
}
});

Step 2

Collections.sort(names, (String a, String b) -> {
return b.compareTo(a);
});

Step 3

Collections.sort(names, (String a, String b) -> b.compareTo(a));

Step 4

Collections.sort(names, (a, b) -> b.compareTo(a));

docs.title: Imports
docs.text:
example

List<String> myList =
Arrays.asList("a1", "a2", "b1", "c2", "c1");

myList
.stream()
.filter(s -> s.startsWith("c"))
.map(String::toUpperCase)
.sorted()
.forEach(System.out::println);
